references: In contrast, this survey aims to provide a comprehensive overview of FL backdoor attacks and defenses by thoroughly reviewing and analyzing existing works, as summarized in Table 1. Our survey differs from previous ones in that we focus on the functioning mechanism and evolution of FL backdoor attacks, as well as the interconnection between different attack strategies and their limitations. We also evaluate the effectiveness of defense mechanisms in terms of their robustness against various attack schemes, including physical attacks. Through this analysis, we aim to improve the understanding of FL backdoor attacks and their consequences, and to assist academia and industry in developing more robust FL systems.

S2.T2.caption: Table 2: Terminology Definitions
S2.T2.table:
Terminology Definition Exchangeable Terms
Orchestration server The server has the power to manage the communication and information of participating clients in the FL system Central server, Federated server, FL server, Aggregator
Benign clients Clients training with benign settings and are not controlled by any adversary Honest clients
Malicious clients Clients training with poisoning settings and are controlled by an adversary Compromised clients, Dishonest clients
Poisoned sample The modified training sample used in poisoning-based backdoor attacks was used to implant backdoor(s) in the model during the training phase N/A
Trigger The pattern is embedded in the poisoned samples and it is used to activate the hidden backdoor(s) Backdoor key
Backdoor target The objective of the backdoor attack which describes the specific characteristics of poisoned samples and the corresponding targeted class or label Adversarial task, Backdoor task
Black-box attack The adversary has no knowledge about the target model, and is only able to replace their local data set N/A
White-box attack The adversary is able to manipulate the training data and local model training’s parameters N/A
Full-box attack The adversary has complete control over the local training process and can replace the training protocol, i.e., using sub-training process to learn the transformation model which outputs backdoored samples N/A
Continuous attack The backdoor attacks are carried out continuously during the training process, either by all communication rounds or a portion of them N/A
Single-shot attack During the training process, the malicious client(s) are selected in only a single round of training N/A
Collusion The adversary controls more than one clients and requires their poisoned updates to facilitate the backdoor attack N/A
Poisoned Model Rate The ratio of malicious clients per total in FL PMR
references: This section presents concise definitions and descriptions of technical terms used in FL systems, backdoor attacks, and defenses in Table 2. These definitions will be consistently referred to throughout the remainder of the survey.

references: We first compare the existing attacks in the following eight dimensions in Table 3. Then, we explain in detail each dimension considered to compare in Table 4.

S5.T4.caption: Table 4: The Primary Dimensions of a Backdoor Attack in FL
S5.T4.table:
Dimension Attribute Values Description
Backdoor Characteristics Attack vector Data Poisoning The adversary is able to manipulate the poisoned data on compromised clients. The clients use this data to compute their local updates.
Model Poisoning The adversary is able to break into the compromised clients and directly controls the training processes and manipulate the local updates.
Backdoor key Input-instance key The targeted specific samples of the backdoor task are the samples naturally containing specific characteristics.
Pattern key The targeted specific samples of the backdoor task are the samples containing intentionally-inserted patterns.
Attacker Capability Highest Accessibility Black-box The adversary has no knowledge about the target model, and is only able to replace their local data set.
White-box The adversary is able to manipulate the training data and local model training’s parameters.
Full-box The adversary has full control of local training process and is able to replace training protocol.
Participant Collusion Non-colluding Each adversary controls one and only one participating client.
Colluding The adversary has full control over several participants in FL system.
Attack frequency Single-shot During the training process, the malicious client(s) are selected in only a single round of training.
Continuous The backdoor attacks are carried out continuously during the training process, either by all communication rounds or a portion of them.
Attack Efficiency Training Stage Constraint Early-round The backdoor is effective even when it is inserted in the early training rounds.
Converged-round The backdoor is effective only when it is implanted when the global model is close to convergence.
Backdoor durability Fair The durability of the backdoor is diluted significantly after the attacker stops participating.
Extended The durability of the backdoor is remained after the attacker stops participating.
Stealthiness consideration YES The adversary tries to avoid detection by employing additional techniques to constraint the abnormal updates from malicious clients.
NO The stealthiness of the attack is not mentioned or evaluated.
references: We first compare the existing attacks in the following eight dimensions in Table 3. Then, we explain in detail each dimension considered to compare in Table 4.

references:
Adversaries and defenders are engaged in a never-ending battle. The conflict between them deepens our understanding of backdoor attacks. Attackers are always looking for ways to make poisoned attacks more covert, effective, and resistant to countermeasures. The primary objective for defenders is to successfully thwart as many kinds of unexpected backdoor attacks as possible.
We summarize attack strategies and the corresponding applicable defenses in Table 5.

As shown in Table 5, most of defense strategies focus on the scenarios of label-flipping backdoor attacks, in which the adversary changes the label of targeted inputs into his expected one.
Although a defense is often designed against multiple attacks, many attack strategies have not been addressed such as: noise-instance, coordinated-trigger, information leakage based, and partially poisoning backdoor attacks.
